q: Which of the following is one of the four earliest civilisations in the world?
desc: The Indus Valley Civilisation is one of the four earliest civilisations, along with Mesopotamian, Egyptian, and Chinese civilisations.

q: What is the estimated period of the Indus Valley Civilisation based on radiocarbon dating?
desc: Radiocarbon dating places the Indus Valley Civilisation between 2500 BC and 1750 BC.

q: Which system was used for Indus Valley town planning?
desc: The Indus cities were laid out in a grid pattern, indicating advanced town planning.

q: What material was commonly used in building Indus Valley houses?
desc: Burnt bricks were used in constructing houses in the Indus Valley Civilisation.

q: What was a major feature of Indus Valley urban infrastructure?
desc: The Indus Valley had an advanced drainage system connected to every house.

q: What is the Citadel in Indus Valley towns?
pool: A fortified upper part of town
answer: A fortified upper part of town
desc: The Citadel was the elevated and fortified area of Indus cities, likely for administrative or ritual use.

q: Which feature is NOT associated with the Indus Valley Civilisation?
desc: There is no evidence of iron usage in the Indus Valley Civilisation.

q: What was the Great Bath at Mohenjodaro used for?
desc: The Great Bath was likely used for ritual purification or religious bathing.

q: Where were six granaries found in a row in the Indus Valley?
desc: Six granaries in a row were discovered at Harappa's Citadel.

q: How were Indus Valley towns typically divided?
desc: Towns were divided into an upper Citadel and a lower residential/commercial area.

q: Who ruled the Harappan people according to archaeological findings?
desc: No weapons have been found, suggesting a peaceful society possibly led by merchants.

q: Why did Indus people sow seeds in November?
desc: They sowed in November to avoid monsoon floods and harvested by April.

q: Which of the following crops was NOT produced by Indus Valley people?
desc: There is no evidence of maize cultivation in the Indus Valley Civilisation.

q: What name did Greeks use for cotton from the Indus region?
desc: The Greeks called Indian cotton 'Sindon', derived from the region of Sindh.

q: Which animal was known to the Indus Valley people?
desc: Oxen were among the many animals domesticated by Indus Valley people.

q: Which of the following animals was NOT known to the Indus Valley people?
desc: There is no evidence suggesting that lions were known to or domesticated by Indus Valley people.

q: Which of these is a feature of Indus Valley drainage system?
desc: Indus drains were covered and systematically connected to every house.

q: What type of economy is indicated by absence of weapons in Indus Valley?
desc: Lack of weapons suggests a peaceful, non-militaristic society.

q: Which crop made the Indus Valley famous internationally?
desc: Indus Valley people were the first to produce cotton, gaining international recognition.

q: Which of the following was NOT a characteristic of Indus cities?
desc: No iron tools have been found from Indus Valley sites.

q: What evidence supports the claim that Harappans were not ruled by kings?
desc: The absence of weapons suggests a society not ruled by military power or kings.

q: Which crop was NOT mentioned as cultivated by Indus people?
desc: Soybean is not listed among the crops produced by Indus Valley farmers.

q: Which site features the famous Great Bath?
desc: The Great Bath, a unique water tank with ritual importance, was found in Mohenjodaro.

q: What evidence shows cotton was produced in the Indus Valley?
desc: Cotton evidence comes from tools, textile remnants, and Greek references to 'Sindon'.

q: Why did Indus people harvest their crops by April?
desc: Harvesting by April helped them avoid seasonal floods in the river valley.

q: Which system of trade was prevalent in the Indus Valley Civilisation?
desc: The Indus people practiced a barter system for trade, exchanging goods directly without using money.

q: Which metal was unknown to the people of the Indus Valley Civilisation?
desc: Iron was not known to the people of the Indus Valley Civilisation.

q: The Indus Valley people used weights and measures based on multiples of which number?
desc: Weights and measures in the Indus Valley were typically based on multiples of 16.

q: What did Harappans associate the Earth with?
desc: The Harappans considered Earth a fertility goddess and practiced related worship.

q: Which form of worship was prevalent in the Indus Valley?
desc: Lingam and yoni worship were part of the fertility cult in Indus Valley religion.

q: Which animal was most worshipped in the Indus Valley?
desc: The unicorn appears frequently on seals and is believed to be the most worshipped animal.

q: Which tree was considered sacred in the Indus Valley Civilisation?
desc: The pipal tree was venerated by the Indus people as sacred.

q: Which bird was worshipped in the Indus Valley?
desc: Birds like the dove and pigeon were also objects of worship in the Indus Valley.

q: What is notable about Indus Valley burial practices?
desc: Dead bodies in the Indus Valley were buried in a North-South orientation.

q: Which animals are depicted on the Seal of Pashupati?
desc: The Seal of Pashupati shows various animals including elephant, tiger, rhinoceros, and buffalo.

q: What animals appear at the feet of Pashupati in the famous seal?
desc: Two deers are shown at the feet of Pashupati in the seal.

q: What did Indus people use to protect against evil forces?
desc: Amulets were used to ward off evil spirits and ghosts.

q: What archaeological sites show the presence of fire altars?
desc: Fire altars were found at Lothal and Kalibangan, indicating ritualistic practices.

q: What is considered the greatest artistic creation of the Harappan culture?
desc: The seals made of steatite are the most remarkable artistic creations of Harappan culture.

q: What material were Harappan seals primarily made of?
desc: Seals were mostly carved from soft steatite stone and then fired.

q: What kind of script did the Harappans use?
desc: The Harappan script was pictographic and remains undeciphered.

q: What is the name of the writing style where lines alternate direction?
desc: Boustrophedon is the writing style where one line is written right-to-left, the next left-to-right.

q: Which direction was the first line written in Boustrophedon style?
desc: The first line of Harappan script in Boustrophedon style was written from right to left.

q: Which of these was NOT an occupation in the Indus Valley?
desc: Spinning, weaving, boat-making, and seal-making were known occupations; software development was not.

q: Which activity was a known profession in the Harappan economy?
desc: Goldsmiths were among the skilled artisans in Harappan society.

q: Which of the following is NOT a suggested reason for the decline of the Indus Civilisation?
desc: No historical evidence supports alien attack as a cause of decline.

q: Which of the following is a suggested cause for the decline of Indus Valley Civilisation?
desc: One theory suggests Aryan invasions led to the decline of the civilisation.

q: Which is the northern boundary site of the Indus Civilisation?
desc: Mandu (in Jammu & Kashmir) marks the northern extent of the civilisation.

q: Which site represents the southern boundary of the Indus Valley Civilisation?
desc: Daimabad in Maharashtra is considered the southern boundary of the civilisation.

q: What is the easternmost site of the Indus Valley Civilisation?
desc: Alamgirpur, located in Uttar Pradesh, is the easternmost site of the Indus Valley Civilisation.

q: Which site marks the western boundary of the Indus Civilisation?
desc: Sutkagendor, located in Baluchistan (Pakistan), is the westernmost site of the Indus region.

q: Which of the following professions was practiced in the Indus Valley?
desc: Boat-making was a vital occupation for trade and transport in the Indus Valley.

q: What kind of trade system did the Indus Valley people have?
desc: The Harappans maintained strong internal and external trade networks.

q: Which of the following statements about Harappan script is true?
desc: The Harappan script is pictographic and still undeciphered.
